title: 107_s1733
content: The Act titled "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" establishes an interoperable law enforcement and intelligence data system with name matching capacity and training. The Act "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" mandates the development of a unified electronic data system by key government agencies to facilitate visa issuance and alien admissibility determinations. The system must have name matching capacity across different databases. The unified electronic database mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be searchable on a linguistically sensitive basis, provide user support, consult with private sector firms, utilize commercially available platforms, and be continuously improved based on experience and technological advancements. The unified electronic database required by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must be searchable using linguistically sensitive algorithms that account for variations in name formats and transliterations in at least 4 designated languages. Advanced linguistic, mathematical, statistical, and anthropological research methods should be incorporated. Adequate user support is also necessary. The unified electronic data system mandated by the "Name Matching for Enforcement and Security Act of 2001" must provide easily accessible information on names in different languages and a means for users to communicate with experts. Additionally, interim reports must be submitted every 6 months by specified government officials. The Director of Central Intelligence must complete a survey and issue a report within 60 days of the Act's enactment. The Director of Intelligence must issue guidelines and submit a copy within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1998 authorizes appropriations for the development and implementation of a data system. Various government agencies must consult with relevant entities in this process. The data system must adhere to a technology standard established by law. The Intelligence Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 1998 authorizes the development of a data system under section 403(c) of the USA PATRIOT Act. The data system allows access to information for Foreign Service officers issuing visas and Federal agents determining alien admissibility. Restrictions on access to intelligence information are established by the Secretary of State, Attorney General, and Director of Central Intelligence.
